Listening makes change. Learning from others‚Äô stories makes change. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important that these courageous students are speaking truth to power. As I prepare to make our case to my colleagues tomorrow, I urge you to keep speaking out. Raise your voices. Call for change.

The minute you meet a parent who‚Äôs lost a teenage child to gun violence, everything changes. From that moment, and for my entire service in the Senate, I‚Äôve proudly voted against the NRA and have had an ‚ÄúF‚Äù rating.

I came from a hunting family and when I first came to Congress, I had an ‚ÄúA‚Äù rating from the NRA. But 9 years ago when I came to the Senate, I met with the victims of gun violence and listened to their stories.

These votes are about keeping our children safe in schools. 
These votes will help keep people safe on the streets of their own communities. These votes will honor the tireless work of activists who‚Äôve been speaking out against the scourge of gun violence for years.

We need to ban automatic weapons and bump stocks. 
We need to pass universal background checks and close the gun show loophole. 
We need to make sure those with a history of violent crimes cannot get guns.
Tomorrow, I‚Äôm calling on my colleagues to do something about this. We need a vote.

Enough is enough. The NRA may be powerful, but so are you and your voice. I urge you to make your voice heard and say shame on any lawmaker who won‚Äôt stand up to the NRA. Pay attention. Find out who. Vote them out this November.
Let me make this clear: This has nothing to do with the Second Amendment and everything to do with greed. The NRA doesn‚Äôt care about people ‚Äì they care about money, and that‚Äôs it.

If my colleagues in Congress are so beholden to the NRA, so paralyzed by its chokehold, that they will turn their backs and bury their heads once again while more children die ‚Äì then this is a monumental failure in leadership.

After this terrible tragedy in Parkland, we‚Äôre seeing the same thing from Congress that we saw after Sandy Hook, after Aurora, after Charleston, after San Bernardino, after Orlando, after Las Vegas, after Sutherland Springs: complete inaction.
